claim: Cancer can cause excess adrenaline production.

supporting.text: Certain tumors, such as pheochromocytomas, are known to secrete excessive adrenaline and other catecholamines, directly linking cancer to adrenaline overproduction.

attacks.text: Certain tumors, such as pheochromocytomas, are known to secrete excessive adrenaline and other catecholamines, directly linking cancer to adrenaline overproduction.
Pheochromocytomas are rare, accounting for less than 0.2% of all cancers, so they are not representative of most cancers.
Even though pheochromocytomas are rare, their well-documented mechanism of adrenaline overproduction still validates the general claim that cancer can cause excess adrenaline.
Non-pheochromocytoma cancers rarely cause adrenaline overproduction, making the claim misleading for the majority of cancer cases.
Some non-pheochromocytoma cancers (e.g., neuroblastomas) can also disrupt adrenal or sympathetic nervous system function, leading to adrenaline overproduction.

supporting.text: Neuroendocrine tumors can disrupt normal hormone regulation, leading to abnormal adrenaline secretion as part of paraneoplastic syndromes.

attacks.text: Neuroendocrine tumors can disrupt normal hormone regulation, leading to abnormal adrenaline secretion as part of paraneoplastic syndromes.
Neuroendocrine tumors are rare, accounting for less than 2% of all cancers, making this mechanism an unlikely general explanation for excess adrenaline production in most cancer patients.
Many neuroendocrine tumors are non-functional and do not secrete hormones, meaning they would not necessarily lead to excess adrenaline production even if present.
Even rare neuroendocrine tumors are disproportionately represented in cases of paraneoplastic syndromes, making them clinically significant when they do occur.
Stress responses to cancer diagnosis and treatment are far more common causes of excess adrenaline than direct tumor effects.
Paraneoplastic syndromes often present before cancer diagnosis, making them important early indicators distinct from treatment-related stress responses.

supporting.text: Metastatic cancers affecting the adrenal glands may interfere with their function, potentially causing dysregulated adrenaline release.

attacks.text: Metastatic cancers affecting the adrenal glands may interfere with their function, potentially causing dysregulated adrenaline release.
Most metastatic cancers do not target the adrenal glands, making this a rare scenario.
Adrenal dysfunction from cancer is more likely to cause hormone deficiency rather than excess adrenaline.
Even rare cases are clinically significant when they occur, especially in metastatic cancer patients.
Some adrenal metastases can cause hypersecretion by stimulating residual functional tissue.

supporting.text: Chronic stress from cancer progression can activate the sympathetic nervous system, indirectly increasing adrenaline production as a physiological response.

attacks.text: Chronic stress from cancer progression can activate the sympathetic nervous system, indirectly increasing adrenaline production as a physiological response.
Not all cancer types or stages cause chronic stress significant enough to activate the sympathetic nervous system.
Even in less aggressive cancers, localized pain or psychological distress can still trigger stress responses.
Adrenal medulla dysfunction due to cancer metastasis is a more direct cause of excess adrenaline than stress-induced mechanisms.
Stress-induced adrenaline production and metastasis-related dysfunction often co-occur in advanced cancer patients.

supporting.text: Some cancers produce adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) ectopically, stimulating the adrenal glands to overproduce adrenaline and related hormones.

attacks.text: Some cancers produce adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) ectopically, stimulating the adrenal glands to overproduce adrenaline and related hormones.
Ectopic ACTH production is rare, occurring in less than 1% of all cancer cases.
Even in rare cases, ectopic ACTH production is clinically significant and well-documented in medical literature.
Most adrenaline excess cases are caused by pheochromocytomas or adrenal tumors, not ectopic ACTH production.
While adrenal tumors are more common, the claim specifically addresses cancer-induced adrenaline excess, which includes ectopic ACTH production.
